Oh, I think we will probably see the players wear purple stuff during Domestic Violence Awareness Month (October-maybe not this year but next). Yes, it will be a publicity thing. But, as horrible as the NFL's handling of DV has been, the Rice situation brought it into the public awareness and discourse. The DV Hotlines were overwhelmed with calls during this time. What usually happens behind closed doors   has been exposed.

The bottom line is that the NFL and sponsors are concerned with their bottom lines.  Neither have considered the glaring problem of domestic violence a problem for many years past.  Kudos to social media and the press for bringing issues of domestic violence to public discussion, as only the shameful video of Rice's actions brings the NFL and sponsors to now seek a moral "higher" ground, which is frankly not that high.  While it is really great that the players wear pink stuff during the month of October, but I am loathe to expect anything of substance from the NFL and sponsors regarding this pervasive violent family issue as there is no $$$ in it.

Tomo, the Ebola virus without mutation may not be transmissible through air at this stage (although if it were aerosolized in a cough and went in your eyes I would argue the point) but even were it not, it's still far more virulent and contagious than HIV, wouldn't you agree?  I'm not sure even the US has "the conditions" (i.e., large numbers of hospital beds under sterile precautions) needed to safely isolate and treat patients with this level of contagion.  As the article implies, the more "medieval" approach of confining patients to treatment in their homes (quarantine) may wind up being a better way to manage this awful disease, should it come our way.

The "moderate Arabs on the ground" are NOT "positioned to fill the void."

Even Obama admitted that was fantasy, until beheadings six weeks before midterm elections made action mandatory no matter what.

It does not help the US to engage in fantasy. A real solution begins with reality.

The epidemic is past the tipping point, and massive resources were not poured into it until, as models show, there was already exponential growth in the Ebola Virus Disease epidemic. However, models only provide estimates, and they tend not to account for important social factors, often treating all people as if they were equally at risk. Social networks and behaviors, related to class structure, age groups, government programs, religious affiliations, and ethnic biases can strongly influence the likelihood of transmission to any given person. This was shown in the HIV epidemic in the U.S. and explains why HIV did not become generalized. Nevertheless, the situation in West Africa is now dire. The influx of promised U.S. aid will not be in place for 2 to 4 months and then it will likely provide care for a only small fraction of actively infected people.

Now the focus of public health experts should turn to a massive educational campaign to teach people how to avoid transmission in the home. What is needed for this to work is hundreds of thousands of gallons of disinfectant solution for objects and soap and alcohol for the skin of caregivers.

If there are more than 2000 people sick with Ebola at any time in the next 12 months -- the capacity of the care facilities -- (and this may be the case already in the 3 primarily affected countries) care at home will be the only option. Now it will mean death for many relatives, but these deaths can be prevented.

Words cannot express the depth of regret and outrage at our government and the rest of the industrialized west who, for want of basic relatively inexpensive preventative methods and devices, hundreds of thousands perhaps millions of human beings on the west coast of Africa a quickly being overshadowed by death. We can get attention and appropriations to fight ISIL, but a microscopic "terrorist" Ebola can freely wreck havoc and death on millions.

I would be extremely cautious in relaying on any estimates on how far and fast Ebola will spread. The models being used to create the estimates reported can only be reliable as the data upon which the model is applied. The truth is their is no reliable data upon which to base sny prediction of the spread if Ebola becuase too many vectors of ebola infection are unidentified, missing or unreliable.

The projections also do not include the orders of magnitude of increase in the mutation of Ebola due to the geometrically increasing number of known and unknown instances of Ebola infection. When Ebola mutates into a virus which is spread by the air instead of contact with bodily fluids than all the current models go out the proverbial window. Please note the report did not mention the projection of likelihood of mutation of Ebola, based on rate of spread. The struggling heaalth care workers do not need to hear how the very air within and around the care centers may, at any point now be laden with airborne Ebola.

The panic stricken reaction of the Saudi King was a revelation which has been recognized by fellow Arabs; his failure to see the danger posed to his regime while his country supported terrorists throughout the region which gave rise to 09/11/2001 had escaped his notice evidently.

Secretary Kerry has excelled, way beyond my expectations, in getting these Arab states to participate in the current action. The question is; will they stay involved? Will they recognize the danger posed to their regimes by ISIL and will their populations support those in power or see an opportunity to throw the current administrations overboard and become involved in either internal political disputes or civil wars within their own states? In either case, the US must decline to take sides and let the various parties sort it out for themselves. The Arab-Muslim world is broken; look at the map from the Atlantic eastwards; the most stable Arab nation today is Egypt, and their stability is controlled by the military. Fortunately, the Muslim Brotherhood has lost power there. Turkey is the lone state supporting the Muslim Brotherhood at this time and they also admire the Hamas terrorists.

That Arab writers are now reporting the facts you quote is a departure from the past and would likely displease the rulers of the countries from which they come. They must be in danger as has been demonstrated in the past when assassination was ordered.

May I add that if Israel acted in a rational way to the Hamas and others, using dialogue and not intense violence I would bet that the old anti-Semitism would not arise so virulently.

Usually the Times will not publish my comments. Yet I am acting and stating what I do out of love for Israel, who must get better leaders. This is what must stop before the world embraces anti-semeitic actions.Please look at what the Gazans endured and understand that most Israelis are either willfully blind or blinded because the occupation is basically invisible. I find this all so utterly sad. Will the Times print this truth? We shall see. I personally am heartbroken because the violence is being done in my name. And we must wake up to this asap.

This report is truly frightening, on two levels. First, because of the events it documents, a sign of rising tensions between communities, the progressive dissolution of harmony. Secondly because, terrible as these events are, they likely do not greatly surprise us, or at least not this reader.

Where these tensions, the anti-semitism, anti-islam and anti-immigrant views will take European society in the next few years is uncertain, but in all probability, to places most reasonable Europeans would rather not visit, yet seem unwilling to effectively prevent. Possibly that very reasonableness prevents them from taking effective action.

And what are the major forces behind this tension? As in times of past conflict, religion (specifically "organised religion" rather than private beliefs) and social inequality, or in a word, "greed"; greed for power, greed for privilege, greed for wealth, greed for dominance of one particular world view over others.
